title: dg.differential geometry - Differentiation under the integral sign for a $L^1$-valued function (shape derivative)
body:
Let $d\in\mathbb N$ ; $U\subseteq\mathbb R^d$ be open and $$\mathcal A:=\{\Omega\subseteq U:\Omega	ext{ is bounded and open and }\partial\Omega	ext{ is of class }C^{0,\:1}\};$$ $E:= igcup_{\Omega\in\mathcal A}L^1(\Omega)$ ; $y:\mathcal A	o E$ with $$y(\Omega)\in L^1(\Omega)\;\;\;	ext{for all }\Omega\in\mathcal A;	ag1$$ $	au>0$ and $T_t:U	o U$ be a $C^1$ -diffeomorphism for $t\in[0,\infty)$ with $T_0=\operatorname{id}_D$ and $\det{m D}T_t(x)>0$ for all $(t,x)\in[0,	au)	imes U$ ; $V:= igcup_{t\in[0,\:	au)}T_t(U)$ $v:[0,	au)	imes V	o\mathbb R^d$ be differentiable in the second argument with $$v\left(t,T_t(x)ight)= rac{\partial T}{\partial t}(t,x)\;\;\;	ext{for all }(t,x)\in[0,	au)	imes U;	ag2$$ $\Omega\in\mathcal A$ and $\Omega_t:=T_t(\Omega)$ for $t\in[0,	au)$ ; $\lambda$ denote the Lebesgue measure on $\mathcal B(\mathbb R)$ ; $\sigma_{\partial\Omega}$ denote the surface measure on $\mathcal B(\partial\Omega)$ ; $
u_{\partial\Omega}$ denote the unit outer normal field on $\partial\Omega$ . There is the following well-known result: If $f\in L^1(V)$ is differentiable, then the functional $$\mathcal F(A):=\int_Af\:{m d}\lambda^{\otimes d}\;\;\;	ext{for }A\in\mathcal A$$ is "shape differentiable at $\Omega$ in direction $v$ ", i.e. $$ rac{\mathcal F(\Omega_t)-\mathcal F(\Omega_0)}t\xrightarrow{t	o0+}\int_{\partial\Omega}f\langle v_0,
u_{\partial\Omega}angle\:{m d}\sigma_{\partial\Omega}	ag3.$$ Now let $Y:[0,	au)	o E_d$ with $$\left.Y(t)ight|_{\Omega_t}=y(\Omega_t)\;\;\;	ext{for all }t\in[0,	au).$$ Then $y$ is called shape differentiable at $\Omega$ in direction $v$ if $Y$ is Fréchet differentiable at $0$ . In that case, $$y'(\Omega)(v):=\left.Y'(0)ight|_{\Omega}	ag4.$$ How can we show that $(4)$ does not depend on the choice of $Y$ ? Let $Y_i$ be two choices of $Y$ . Clearly, $$0=\int_{\Omega_t}(Y_1(t)-Y_2(t))\varphi\:{m d}\lambda^{\otimes d}	ag5$$ for all $\varphi\in C_c^\infty(U)$ . But why does differentiating $(5)$ with respect to $t$ yield $$0=\int_\Omega(Y_1'(0)-Y_2'(0))\varphi\:{m d}\lambda^{\otimes d}+\int_{\partial\Omega}(Y_1(0)-Y_2(0))\varphi\langle v_0,
u_{\partial\Omega}angle\:{m d}\sigma_{\partial\Omega}	ag5?$$ The second term on the right-hand side of $(5)$ seems to be an application of $(3)$ for $f=Y_1(0)-Y_2(0))\varphi$ . But where does the first term come from?
